msDesc.head: Poetic anthology on the courtly game of love; England, 15th century, third quarter

msContents.textLang: Middle English with Latin and Anglo-Norman

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Complaint of the Black Knight
msItem.incipit:
So doth this god with his sharp flone
The trew sleith & letith the fals gone
msItem.explicit:
Exiled be that I may not atteyne
Recure to fynde of myne aduersyte
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit the Compleynt of a loveres life

msItem.title: Anelida’s Complaint
msItem.rubric: The complaynte of feyre Anelida ouer fals Arcyte
msItem.incipit:
So thyrlid with the poynt of Remembraunce
The swerd of sorow I whet with fals plesavnce
msItem.explicit:
Now that Arcite Anelida to fore
Hath thirled with the poynt of remembraunce.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit So thirlid with the poynte of Remembraunce

msItem.title: Anelida and Arcite
msItem.rubric: The boke of feyre Anelida & fals Arcyte
msItem.incipit:
The fers god of Armes Mars the rede
that in the frosty contre callid trace
msItem.explicit:
And with her owne hond she gan hit write
& sent hit to her theban knght Arcyte
msItem.finalRubric: So thrillyd with the poynt. vt supra et cetera

msItem.author: John Clanvowe (?)
msItem.title: The Cuckoo and the Nightingale
msItem.rubric: The boke of Cupide god of loue
msItem.incipit:
The god of loue a benedicite
how mighti & how grete a lorde is he
msItem.explicit:
Terme of life loue hath withhold me
so loude that with that songe I a woke
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit the boke of Cupyde god of loue

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Temple of Glass
msItem.incipit:
For thoght constrynt & grevous heuynesse
ffor pensifhed & for high distresse
msItem.explicit:
I mene that benigne & goodly of hir face
Now go thi wey & put the in hir grace

msItem.author: Thomas Hoccleve
msItem.title: Letter of Cupid
msItem.rubric: The Lettre Of Cupide god of Loue
msItem.incipit:
Cvpide vnto whos commaundement
The gentill kynrede of goddis an hye
msItem.explicit:
The yere of grace ioifull & iocunde
A thousand & foure hondrid & secounde
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit the Lettre of Cupide god of loue directide to his suggestys louers

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Complaint unto Pity
msItem.incipit:
Pite that I haue sought so yore ago
with hert sore & full of besy peyne
msItem.explicit:
Thus for youre deth I may well wepe & pleyne
With herte sore & full of besy peyne

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Legend of Good Women
msItem.rubric: The Prologe of ix good women
msItem.incipit:
A Thowsand sithes I haue herd tell
Ther ys ioy in hevin & peyn in hell
msItem.explicit:
and then she was kaught & fetryd in prycoun
this tale ys seide for this conclusioun

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Parliament of Fowls
msItem.incipit:
Cometh al this new corne fro yere to yere
And out of olde bokys in good feyth
msItem.explicit:
That I shall mete som thinge for to fare
The bet & thus to rede I will not spare
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit tractatus de congregacione volucrum die Sancti Valentini

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Book of the Duchess
msItem.incipit:
I haue grete wondir be this light
how that I leue for day ne nyght
msItem.explicit:
As I kan best & that Anone
This was my sweuyn now it ys done
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit The Boke of the Duchesse

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: House of Fame
msItem.incipit:
God turne vs euery dreme to good
ffor a ys wondre by the rode
msItem.explicit:
Be he semyd for to be
A man of grete auctoryte

msItem.title: On the chance of the dice
msItem.incipit:
Fyrst myn vnkunnyng & my Rudenesse
Vnto you all that listen know her chaunce
msItem.explicit:
ffor hasard hath with maistry quytte me so
My while that I ioyles now leue yn wo
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit The Chaunce of the Dyse
msItem.note: Folio 195 torn; fols. 197, 201 mutilated; lacks lines 295–336.

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: ABC hymn to the Virgin
msItem.incipit:
Almighty & almercyable quene
To whom all this world fleith for socor
msItem.explicit:
Bringe os to that paleis that is bilte
To penitentis that ben to mercy abull

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Ballad of Fortune
msItem.incipit:
This wrechid worldis transmutacion
As wele & wo now pore & now honoure
msItem.rubric: (fol. 208v) La Repons du ffortune Au pleyntyff
msItem.explicit:
Praieth his best ffrende of his noblesse
That to som bettyr estate he may Atteyne

msItem.title: The complaint against hope
msItem.incipit:
As I stode in studyenge allone
Astonyed in studye well colde
msItem.explicit:
Than I do that I with yen se
hope yn hope out thus kan ye folys fede

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer (?)
msItem.title: Compleint Damours
msItem.incipit:
I which that am the sorwefullist man
That in this worlde was euyr yit leuynge
msItem.explicit:
And yit wull I euyrmore hir serue
And loue hir best although she do me sterue

msItem.title: Ragman's Roll
msItem.incipit:
My ladies & my mastressys echon
like hit vnto youre humble womanhede
msItem.explicit:
And yn the Rolle last as yn wrytynge
I rede that this game ende yn youre hood

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Order of Fools
msItem.incipit:
The ordre of ffolys well yare age bigonne
Newly provessid encrecyth the Couente
msItem.explicit:
Or when that sperado louyth paramours
On of the noumbre that will neure the
msItem.note: Fol. 219v is half erased by ill usage, and a leaf or two are wanting after it: only the first six stanzas are here, omitting lines 41–48 and 57–176.

supportDesc.support: Parchment forms the outermost and centre bifolia of each quire; the remaining leaves are paper. Watermarks, quires 1–7 (fols. 1r–111v): a crown with centre piece of lance heads, cf. Heawood 1929, fig. 27; quires 8–10 (fols. 112r–59v), grapes, cf. Briquet nos. 12992–13006; quire 11 (fols. 160r–75v), bull, cf. Briquet no. 2783; quires 12–14 (fols. 176r–219v), mount, cf. Briquet no. 11706.
supportDesc.collation: Signatures and text indicate that the first and last quires have been lost. The leaves remaining are arranged as 116 (fols. 1-16), 220 (fols. 17–36), 316 (fols. 37–52), 414 (fols. 53–66), 516 (fols. 67–82), 616–1 (fols. 83–97; 14th excised, before fol. 96), 716–2 (fols. 98–111; 2nd and 15th excised, before fols. 99 and 111), 8–1216 (fols. 112–91), 1316–1 (fols. 192–206; 11th excised, before fol. 202), 1414 (fols. 207–220; 13th excised, before fol. 219). Catchwords enclosed in scrolls at the centre foot of final leaves. Signatures in the outer corner of the opening leaf of each quire, most cropped in binding; those still legible are ij (fol. 1r), iiij (fol. 37r), viij (fol. 98r).

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in dry point, or brown or red ink, written in 21–36 long lines, ruled space 144–154 85

handDesc.handNote: Written in gothic cursiva antiquior, apparently by a single scribe.

decoDesc.decoNote: Rubrics, running heads, paraphs, and brackets for poetic structure in red.

binding.p: Early seventeenth-century binding from the Bodleian Library, reversed calf over laminated pulpboard with printed binding waste used as pastedowns. Formerly chained.

accMat.p: Upper pastedown: upper portion of an edition of Nicholas de Tudeschis’ commentary on the Decretals from the late fifteenth or early sixteenth centuries.
Lower pastedown: edition of Rudolph Agricola’s De inuentione dialectica from the early sixteenth century.

history.origin:
15th century, third quarter
English Possibly written by a Lity or Lyty (inscribed, fols. 4v, 7r, 38r, 45v, 209v), whose initials appear to be JL (fol. 141r).
history.provenance: Numerous sixteenth-century inscriptions, possibly indicating ownership by a school, include Richard Becher (fols. 17r, 159r), James Hedington (fol. 83v), be me Humffrey Fflemyn (Humfrey Flemyng?, fol. 214r, cf. 127r, 162r), Antony Sherington in Lemsster (Leominster), 1563 (fol. 36v, cf. 144v), John Smart (fol. 191r), S. Pot (fols. 193v, 194r), TH 1573 (fol. 194v).

Robert Copland (fl. 1505–1547) used the manuscript as the printer’s copy in his edition of The Parliament of Fowls for Wynkyn de Worde in 1530. See Mary C. Erler, ‘Printers’ Copy: MS Bodley 638 and the “Parliament of Fowls”’, The Chaucer Review, 33.3 (1999), 221–29.
history.acquisition: Apparently acquired between 1613 and 1620. Former shelfmarks: MS T.9.7 Iur (fol. i recto and 1620 catalogue), NE C.3.10 (fol. i recto). An inscription Gyl: Astley 1410 (upper pastedown) may be from a Giles Astley (died 1666) who was an undergraduate at Hart Hall in the 1630s.

recordHist.source: Description by Andrew Dunning (August 2022), drawing on the Digital Index of Middle English Verse and the more detailed description by Pamela Robinson, Manuscript Bodley 638: A Facsimile (Norman, OK, 1982). Previously described in the Summary Catalogue (1922): Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 199 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 200

ref.title: Digital Index of Middle English Verse

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning Revised with consultation of original.
Description revised to include all information in SC.
